page.title: 12Fishing on the River Severn
page.content: Salmon fishing is important but needs no explanation;elvering is less widely known about in the country at large though here,along these reaches of the Severn,it is a common sight in March to see elvering nets on the roof-racks of cars.Elvers,which are baby eels and are greyish finger-length creatures rather thinner than a drinking straw,are caught in specially shaped fine-mesh nets in the spring when the tide is right.Much fishing is done at night and you can see the dotted lights of fishing parties along the banks as they scoop out the wriggling prey.Elvers are eaten whole,fried in a mass like whitebait,but nowadays much is sent by air to places such as Japan for about Â£1 per lb.One consignment this March(1985)went to start a new life in Irish lakes as it was sent to stock those waters.
